Physician wrote a RR report that says: EXAMINATION:  MR HEAD W AND W/O CONTRAST T9112 MR HEAD

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with SSS, single episode of AF a/w paresthesia in
L face, arm, leg. Eval for prior strokes// intermittent paresthesias a/w AF on
device

TECHNIQUE:  Sagittal and axial T1 weighted imaging were performed. After
administration of intravenous contrast, axial imaging was performed with
gradient echo, FLAIR, diffusion, and T1 technique. Sagittal MPRAGE imaging was
performed and re-formatted in axial and coronal orientations.

COMPARISON:  None.

FINDINGS: 

There is a 4 mm T2 hyperintense enhancing lesion along the floor of the right
anterior cranial fossa, it has flattened appearance, overlying right anterior
orbital gyrus, most likely extra-axial.  Findings most consistent with
meningioma in the absence of history of malignancy.  Slightly decreased T2
signal in this area, suggestive of mineralization.  No associated edema.

Mild prominence of perivascular spaces midbrain, basal ganglia, cerebral
hemispheres.  Evidence of hemorrhage, edema, mass effect, midline shift or
infarction.   The ventricles and sulci are normal in caliber and
configuration.

Minimal mucosal thickening paranasal sinuses.  Clear mastoids.  Vascular flow
voids are preserved.  High riding right jugular bulb.

IMPRESSION: 

4 mm enhancement along floor of right anterior cranial fossa, most consistent
with meningioma.
.

Physician wrote a RR report that says: EXAMINATION:
Chest:  Frontal and lateral views

INDICATION:  History: ___ with chest pain  // eval heart and lungs

TECHNIQUE:  Chest:  Frontal and Lateral

COMPARISON:  None.

FINDINGS: 

Patient is status post median sternotomy and CABG.  No pleural effusion is
seen.  There is no pneumothorax.  Patchy right apical opacity is seen of
indeterminate age ; could represent scarring, however, underlying
consolidation due to infection is not excluded.  Recommend comparison with
prior studies to demonstrate long-term stability or followup to resolution. 
Multiple old right-sided rib deformities are seen suggesting prior trauma.

IMPRESSION: 

Patchy right upper lobe opacity could relate to scarring, however, focal
consolidation due to infection is not excluded.  Recommend comparison with
prior studies to demonstrate long-term stability or followup to resolution.
.

Physician wrote a RR report that says: EXAMINATION:  CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST

INDICATION:  History: ___ with fall, head strike, left lateral face abrasions
and tenderness  // Eval for injury

TECHNIQUE:  Noncontrast enhanced MDCT images of the head were obtained. 
Reformatted coronal and sagittal images were also obtained.

Dose:
 This study involved 4 CT acquisition phases with dose indices as follows:
   1) CT Localizer Radiograph
   2) CT Localizer Radiograph
   3) Sequenced Acquisition 20.0 s, 20.5 cm; CTDIvol = 54.3 mGy (Head) DLP =
1,114.9 mGy-cm.
   4) Spiral Acquisition 10.6 s, 22.1 cm; CTDIvol = 53.8 mGy (Head) DLP =
1,190.5 mGy-cm.
 Total DLP (Head) = 2,305 mGy-cm.

COMPARISON:  None

FINDINGS: 

There is no evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, midline shift, mass
effect, or acute large vascular territorial infarct.  Prominence of the
ventricles and sulci is consistent with atrophy.  Periventricular and
subcortical white matter hypodensities are likely sequelae of chronic small
vessel disease.  There are right basal gangliar lacunar infarcts.  Small
lacunar infarct in the left pons is also seen.  Infarct in the left aspect of
the pons.  The visualized paranasal sinuses demonstrate mild mucosal
thickening in the bilateral maxillary sinuses and ethmoid air cells.  There is
also minimal mucosal thickening of the bilateral frontal sinuses..  The
mastoid air cells are clear.  Calcifications are seen along the cavernous
portions of the carotid arteries.  Small amount of patient motion is seen
through the facial bones however, no acute fracture is seen.

IMPRESSION: 

No acute intracranial process.  No acute fracture seen.
Lacunar infarcts involving the right basal ganglia and the left aspect of the
pons.
.

Physician wrote a RR report that says: EXAMINATION:  CT C-SPINE W/O CONTRAST Q311 CT SPINE

INDICATION:  History: ___ with fall, head strike, left lateral face abrasions
and tenderness  // Eval for injury       Eval for injury

TECHNIQUE:  Non-contrast helical multidetector CT was performed. Axial image
data was collimated to display separate 2.5 mm soft tissue and bone algorithm
axial images.  Coronal and sagittal reformations were then constructed.

DOSE:   This study involved 3 CT acquisition phases with dose indices as
follows:
   1) CT Localizer Radiograph
   2) CT Localizer Radiograph
   3) Spiral Acquisition 6.7 s, 26.3 cm; CTDIvol = 37.3 mGy (Body) DLP = 981.3
mGy-cm.
 Total DLP (Body) = 981 mGy-cm.

COMPARISON:  None.

FINDINGS: 

Mild degenerative changes are seen, including disc space narrowing at C5/C6
and posterior osteophyte at this level.  There is minimal loss of height of
the C4 and C5 vertebral bodies of indeterminate age, but felt to most likely
not acute.  There is minimal retrolisthesis of to C4 over C5.  No frank
dislocation is seen.  There is a likely old right rib fracture.  There is no
prevertebral soft tissue swelling.

The partially imaged lung apices demonstrate pulmonary emphysema, both
centrilobular and paraseptal, as well as apical scarring

IMPRESSION:


1. Minimal loss of height of the C4 and C5 vertebral bodies of indeterminate
age, but felt unlikely acute.  Correlate with site of point tenderness.  No
evidence of acute fracture seen elsewhere.  Minimal retrolisthesis of C4 over
C5.
.

___ y/o M with a h/o CAD s/p CABG, high-grade CAD on recent cath

crack cocaine abuse, presenting with chest pain in the setting

ACTIVE PROBLEMS
# Chest pain: In ED concern for stable angina in the setting of 
CAD and recent cocaine use. Chest pain free since admission, 
feels well the morning after admission with no further pain, no 
dyspnea, no new symptoms. EKG without definite ischemic change, 
and troponins were negative x2. Anion gap was 19 on admission, 
but gap had closed as of the morning. His Atenolol was increased 
from 25mg to 50mg, and he was continued on daily ASA 81mg. Due 
to the negative troponins, lack of EKG changes, and resolution 
of symptoms, he was determined to be safe for discharge and for 
him to continue his plan of going to a Detox center.

# HTN: Systolic BP 170's on arrival to floor, 130's the morning 
after admission. Only home medication is Atenolol 25mg, which 
was increased to 50mg.

but developed the chest pain and went to the hospital instead. 
Recent cocaine and EtOH abuse, potentially contributing to Chest 
pain and elevated BP's on admission. Social work was consulted, 
and provided Mr. ___ with a list of places where he could go 
for detox. While in-hospital he was kept on the CIWA protocol, 
with Diazepam PRN for CIWA over 10, which was not needed.
